sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Swift and severe response. In a show of unity, Western allies warn Russia once again that there will be a heavy price to pay for invading Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: A former pope in the crosshairs. A long-awaited report says Benedict XVI failed to act in child sex abuse cases while he was Archbishop of Munich. He denies any wrongdoing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Blackmail and intimidation. A Conservative Party MP says those calling for a confidence vote in the British Prime Minister are being threatened with funding cuts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And around the world at the age of 19, British-Belgian teenager Sarah Rutherford becomes the youngest woman to fly solo across five continents.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the program. I'm Stefan Grobe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: France, Germany, the UK and the US have held talks in Berlin

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: in an effort to try and degree a joint position if Russia decides to invade Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken met his European counterparts before he heads to Vienna on Friday to meet Russia's foreign minister Sergei Lavrov. The last two weeks have seen several rounds of talks within Europe, as worries over the rising number of Russian troops along Ukraine's borders have increased.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: While the US and Germany have emphasized the importance of continuing talks with Russia, both agree that Moscow's actions will be met with consequences. We urge Russia to take steps to de-escalate the situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Any further aggression will have decisive consequences.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We fight for the continuation of the European peaceful system, which is existential for us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Russia is continuing to escalate its threat toward Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We've seen that again in just the last few days, with increasingly bellicose rhetoric, building up its forces on Ukraine's borders, including now in Belarus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: Russia's repeatedly turned away from agreements that have kept the peace across the continent for decades.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: And it continues to take aim at NATO, a defensive, voluntary alliance that protects nearly a billion people across Europe and North America, and at the governing principles of international peace and security that we all have a stake in defending.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia says NATO is also raising tensions, as Poland, Lithuania and Ukraine all increase troop numbers, something Moscow says it will be compelled to respond to.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We share the concerns of Belarusian colleagues and allies that NATO has been beefing up its military presence along the external borders of Belarus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They do not provide any explanations, none whatsoever.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's obvious that these are provocative actions, but they do not feel any need to give any explanations or justification.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In this regard, Russia and Belarus are compelled to counteract adequately.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This includes combined policing of the airspace, regular joint training, drills and so on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Let's bring in our reporter Kate Brady in Berlin, the center of frantic diplomacy today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Kate. Good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So this was a day of forging a common Western position here before the Blinken-Lavrov talks later this week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Do they have something up their sleeve to defuse the crisis?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, concretely speaking, the main strategy right now is dialogue, dialogue, dialogue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And we've seen that in the flurry of diplomatic talks that have been going on around Europe this week between NATO allies. And that's something that German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock reiterated during Antony Blinken's visit today. She said that the only way out of this crisis is a political one, reiterating, again, the need for more dialogue. But the Allies did also today discuss possible sanctions should there indeed be a Russian invasion of Ukraine. And one of those options could potentially be or involve at least this controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, that pipeline that runs between Russia and Germany, which is now completed but hasn't yet been signed off on the German side.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Now, Germany is reluctant to halt the final approval of the pipeline, saying they would rather not use it as leverage against Russia should there indeed be an escalation at the border to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But Antony Blinken, the U.S. Secretary of State, really upped the pressure on Germany today, saying that the pipeline should and could indeed be used as leverage against Russia because there's not yet any gas running through it. So certainly upping the pressure here on Germany, and it would certainly put Berlin in a very tricky corner, should there indeed be an escalation on the border, which would most likely, as we've heard from Western allies and NATO allies, would most likely result in some very serious consequences and economic consequences as well for Moscow. And Kate what are the expectations of the Blinken-Lavrov talks? What are you hearing? Well the one thing that we do know Blinken will take with him now at least is the united support of NATO allies as he meets with Lavrov.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But it's still not clear exactly whether or not Moscow really sees anything on the table right now that's really worth talking about.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The bottom line is, Moscow wants NATO allies to promise that Ukraine will never become a member of the NATO alliance, something that NATO allies have completely rejected, saying that Russia has no say in what military alliances and groups other countries become part of.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So it's really unclear as to whether or not there's really any room for maneuver right now by discussing other issues as well, whether it's the placement of missiles or where military exercises are held.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Of course, we'll have to wait for the result of those talks tomorrow between Blinken and Lavrov, but it's looking extremely unlikely, very difficult right now to see where there's much room for movement on that front.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: All right, Kate Brady there in Arctic Berlin for us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: France and Germany, the EU's most powerful member states, were involved in today's talks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But the bloc itself has been left out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Let's now head to Brussels and our correspondent Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Shona.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So the bloc will be crucial when it comes to implementing more sanctions against Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Do we already know what measures we could look at?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: No, not at this point, Stefan. We know that the EU just before Christmas was very much aligned when it came to the fact that there would be massive economic consequences against Russia and unfortunately against the Russian people as a result if there is some sort of invasion of Ukraine. And as you mentioned there, of course, the bloc wasn't represented this week in any way in those diplomatic efforts. But the EU will have to shoulder a huge amount of responsibility if there is an invasion, because there'll be no NATO or nobody wants a military confrontation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It'll be down to massive economic sanctions. It'll also be down to the EU to take in any refugees, if that's the way things evolve. So I think the EU does have quite a strong level of responsibility here. Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, was speaking at Davos today, and she reiterated the EU's promise that there would be huge consequences for Russia economically if there is an incursion in Ukraine if the situation deteriorates if there are any further attacks on the territorial Integrity of Ukraine we will respond with massive economic and financial sanctions the transatlantic community stands firm on this. The European Union is by far Russia's biggest trading partner and by far the largest investor. And yes, this trading relationship is important to us, but it is far more important to russia and shona friday obviously a big day for diplomacy what will brussels be looking at well i think most first and foremost whether or not diplomacy still has a chance, Stefan. I mean, we saw last week that the really intense diplomatic efforts didn't yield a huge amount of results.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So that's key, because as we even heard from Kate there, the implications of an invasion of Ukraine will be huge, whether it comes to European energy, whether it comes to the loss of life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So it's a very serious situation that we're in and very hard to come back from if there is an invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: very serious situation that we're in and very hard to come back from if there is an invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Another thing that obviously everybody would be looking for is to whether or not Vladimir Putin knows what he wants to do or what his intentions are over the next few weeks, whether there will be a military incursion or whether we're seeing sabre rattling. We heard from Joe Biden in the White House yesterday. He said that he believes that Vladimir Putin will engage militarily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: yesterday he said that he believes that Vladimir Putin will engage militarily and he even said maybe it may be a small incursion but as we heard from the president of Ukraine there's no such thing as a small incursion so everybody will be watching to see what's potentially going to happen over the next few days and and a few weeks and the the outcome really could have huge consequences Stefan all right Shona Shona, our Brussels correspondent there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The former Pope, Benedict XVI, has been accused of failing to act against four priests

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: who were accused of child sexual abuse.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The alleged incident happened at the time when he was Archbishop of Munich.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He denies the charges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Speaking after the details of a new report into the abuse were revealed, the current Archbishop of Munich in Freising said he's deeply shaken and shocked.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: FR.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: FR.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: FR.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: My first thought goes out to all those who have suffered harm and violence at the hands of priests and other members of the Church.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I'm deeply shaken and shocked.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: For me personally, the conversations with victims have changed my perception of the Church and are still changing it."

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The investigation, carried out by a German law firm, looked at how the Catholic Church handled the abuse allegations. SJ Marcus reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Former Pope Benedict XVI has been heavily incriminated in a new report on the handling of child sex abuse allegations in the Catholic Church in Munich when he was the Archbishop Cardinal Ratzinger.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The four cases came to light when Ratzinger was Cardinal in Munich from 1977 to 1982, before becoming the head of Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We have come to the conclusion that the then Archbishop Cardinal Ratzinger is to be accused of misconduct in the cases of sexual abuse.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The 94-year-old, who resigned as Pope nearly 10 years ago, denies the accusations. In 2018 a church commissioned report found at least 3,677 people were abused by clergy in Germany between 1946 and 2014. More than half of the victims were 13 or younger and nearly a third served as altar boys. Jay Marquis, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government has been accused of

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: blackmailing opponents by one of its own MPs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: William Wreck, who also sits on a parliamentary committee, says MPs who have called for a confidence vote in Boris Johnson's leadership have faced intimidation and threats. His comments add to the already heightened speculation over Johnson's future that have been sparked by allegations of lockdown-breaching parties in Downing Street during nationwide COVID restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But more on this, let's go to London now, where our reporter Tijk Enright is waiting for us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Teich. So today was to be the day of the calm after yesterday's storm of PMQs. But so far we've seen the government being accused of blackmailing MPs and reports that Sue Gray has found damning evidence. Can this go on for much longer?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Hi, Stefan. Well, listen, plenty are convinced here that Boris Johnson is on a one-way street out of office, but he is certainly moving slowly and trying his best to cling on. You're right, this was a day which began feeling like Boris Johnson had dodged a bullet. That move, that reported move against him by some of his MPs yesterday didn't actually materialise. But then two other MPs fired a new bullet, as you mentioned there, William Wragg suggesting that he and other rebels within the Conservative Party have been blackmailed into rowing in behind Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And the MP who sensationally quit the party yesterday, on Wednesday, I should say, for the Labour Party, also said that he too had been blackmailed in the past, convinced to vote in a particular way, perhaps on unpopular legislation, on the threat that funding for a new school in his constituency would be cut off if he didn't.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now supporters of the Prime Minister are pointing out that William Wragg is a long time critic of Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He was one of the first to call for him to resign after the recent scandal about parties in Downing Street and of course the other is the MP who quit the party sensationally.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They're suggesting that these allegations are politically motivated. You ask the question, can this go on for much longer? Well, what it feels like now is that many Conservative MPs are giving Boris Johnson the breathing space which he's asked for to allow Sue Gray, that senior civil servant who's investigating all these lockdown parties in Downing Street, the time to complete her report. We don't know exactly when she's going to do that. Could it be next week? Could it be the following week? And indeed, we don't know exactly whether or not she's going to, you know, clear Boris Johnson of responsibility or even go as far as blaming him. But I think if there is still an appetite among his MPs to move against him, the publication of that report will be the most likely time for that to happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I mean, let's face it, we have Britain in the middle of an energy crisis, a cost of living crisis and we have a Prime Minister who is basically dealing with questions over his own integrity and behavior right? Your thoughts?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well you know that is always the conundrum when a leader is caught up in a scandal. It happens in other countries too, of course.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It becomes a distraction for the business of doing government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Worth pointing out as well, they're also trying to steer their way out of a pandemic here, just like they are in most other countries around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But actually, they are getting on with that business and indeed trying, as some cynics would say, to distract us from the scandal by abruptly lifting several of the latest COVID restrictions, the Omicron COVID restrictions which have applied in England.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: For example, working from home is no longer recommended here in England.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Cynics have questioned whether the timing of all this is political.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Of course, it is happening in other jurisdictions too.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But in part, it's worked in terms of distraction tactic. Right-wing newspapers and commentators who had been criticizing the Prime Minister are now celebrating the end of these restrictions. But I don't think Boris Johnson can relax just yet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's worth restating there are people on the inside in Downing Street who are actively campaigning and briefing against him, who are leaking leaking against him that's why we've seen so many damaging revelations in recent weeks and there could yet be more revelations to come Stefan all right tech and right there in London for us thank you very much the way Google Facebook Amazon and other giant tech

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: platforms influences could be governed by a European Union digital constitution.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The EU hopes that we can have more control with such issues such as targeted adverts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sándor Sirós reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The European Union is preparing a digital constitution which will govern the influence of giant tech platforms like Google, Facebook, Amazon and others.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, lawmakers at the European Parliament are preparing their position on how to enable users have more control over what they are exposed to online.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It comes as consumers are increasingly vulnerable to unprecedented levels of data collection and targeted advertisement from internet giants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: What is illegal in the real world should be made illegal online as well, MEPs say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We will try to make the online environment more safe and more trustworthy for users when they discuss politics, for people who shop goods, for businesses using the platforms to reach out to the businesses and for fundamental rights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So we want to give users of the platforms more rights towards the platforms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The Digital Services Act will update the existing e-commerce directive established in 2000.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: At that time, Facebook didn't even exist.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The legislation will give the EU the ability to erase content containing hate speech, disinformation or counterfeit products.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Users will also be able to stop personalized targeted advertisements. But critics say there are sufficient loopholes in the text which could be misused.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: The main problem from my point of view are the cross-border removal orders which could lead to the deletion of fully legal content in one country just based on a decision taken in another one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: This is particularly dangerous in the current rule of law crisis, where some of the member states are backsliding towards authoritarianism. Giving the tools to diminish freedom of expression is unacceptable and it will definitely not help us to create more smooth digital single market.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now the European Parliament has to agree with the European Council on the text before the law will come into force in all 27 states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sándor Zsíros, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: British-Belgian pilot Zara Rutherford has set a world record

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: as the youngest woman to fly solo around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The 19-year-old touched down in her small airplane in Western Belgium 155 days after she departed. She dedicated her flight to all young women trying to succeed in male-dominated sectors like aviation, but added that she wouldn't be repeating the feat anytime soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I don't think I'll do this again exactly, but I'm looking forward to still speaking to people about my experiences and try and encourage people to do something crazy with their lives.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: If you have the opportunity, then go for it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It takes a lot of time, a lot of patience, a lot of work, but it is incredible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It is difficult, but it is very rewarding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Lithuania has voted in favour of a bill that will allow non-native names and letters to appear on passports and ID forms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The law, if signed off by the president, should put an end to years of gridlock over the subject, which remains a delicate one in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Katie Dartford reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The letters Q, X and W do not exist in the Lithuanian alphabet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The country's parliament has voted to allow the original spelling of non-Lithuanian names in Latin-based characters in personal documents.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The bill means Lithuanian citizens can use them under certain conditions, such as if they take their spouse's non-Lithuanian surname or if their ancestors had citizenship of another country. It's a very important move in terms of human rights and even in terms of security policy related to our neighbouring countries. But first of all, it's a question of human dignity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Currently anyone wanting to have their names in its original spelling in their Lithuanian passport or ID cards have to turn to the courts, which have so far ruled in their favour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: Quoting the late linguistics professor Vincas Urboutis, this is simply a betrayal of the Lithuanian language. Any tricks of the legal committee will not help.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The issue has caused a decade of deadlock and the original spelling of ethnic Poles' names is regularly raised at meetings between Vilnius and Warsaw. The law will only come into force if it's signed by President Gitanas Nozida and there are some MPs asking for the President to veto the bill.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: That's it for this edition. Thank you for watching and goodbye.
